senses.de: To officially choose someone or something for a special job or purpose
senses.ex: The company designated her as the new CEO.

Tips.title: Official Roles
Tips.description: Used when someone is given a formal role or task within an organization.
Tips.example: She was designated as the official spokesperson for the event.

Tips.title: Future Intent
Tips.description: Implies a planned or intended future action, often found in official plans or announcements.
Tips.example: The council designated the old library as a community arts center.

Tips.title: Precise Selection
Tips.description: Implies a careful or deliberate choice out of many possibilities.
Tips.example: From the applicant pool, three were designated for the final interview round.

senses.de: To point out, show, or indicate
senses.ex: He designated the spots where the trees will be planted.

Tips.title: Physical Locations
Tips.description: Often used when specifying locations for specific actions or events, such as construction.
Tips.example: The architect designated where each piece of furniture should go.

Tips.title: Visual Clarity
Tips.description: Implies making something clear or evident, like pointing or marking on a map.
Tips.example: The tour guide designated the rest areas on the map.

Tips.title: Invisible Boundaries
Tips.description: Can refer to the setting of boundaries or limits that are conceptually understood.
Tips.example: The playing field's boundaries were designated by the referee.

senses.de: To give a name or title to something
senses.ex: This day is designated as 'World Environment Day'.

Tips.title: Naming Occasions
Tips.description: Used when a particular day or event is given a special name or title.
Tips.example: July 20th was designated as 'Moon Day' to commemorate the lunar landing.

Tips.title: Formal Recognition
Tips.description: Carries a sense of formality when naming or titling events, places, or objects.
Tips.example: The bridge was designated 'The Freedom Passage' by local authorities.

Tips.title: Cultural Titles
Tips.description: May involve cultural or societal titles, acknowledging traditions or honor.
Tips.example: The elder was designated 'Keeper of the Stories' in the community.

Appoint.wordDefinition:
Appoint means to officially select or assign a person to a position or job.

It is usually used in a formal or professional setting, such as appointing someone as the CEO of a company, or appointing a judge to a court.

Appoint is more specific to selecting a person for a job or position, while designate can refer to selecting something or someone for any purpose or role.

Assign.wordDefinition:
The words assign and designate both mean to give someone or something a task or a name, but they are used in slightly different ways.

To assign means to give someone a specific task or job to do. For example, a teacher might assign homework to their students or a boss might assign a project to their employees.

Assign is more about giving someone a task or responsibility, while designate is more about giving something a specific label or name.

Indicate.wordDefinition:
Indicate means to show or suggest something or someone, usually through a sign or signal. For example, a weather vane might indicate which direction the wind is blowing.

Designate is used to signify official appointments or assignments, while indicate is used to suggest or show something using clues or signs.

Name.wordDefinition:
Name primarily means to give a specific title or label to something or someone. You can name your pet dog or name a new product for your company.

In simpler terms, you designate when you assign a specific use or purpose, while you name when you simply give something a title or label.

Nominate.wordDefinition:
Designate and nominate are two words that refer to choosing or selecting someone or something for a particular role or purpose.

Nominate usually means to suggest or recommend someone or something for a particular role or award. For example, an organization may nominate an individual for an award or a political party may nominate a candidate for an election.

Designate is more formal and involves an official assignment, while nominate is more informal and involves a recommendation or suggestion.

Select.wordDefinition:
Select means to choose or pick something out of a group or list of options. For example, a person might select their favorite flavor of ice cream from a menu.

Both words are applicable in various situations, but designate is more commonly used in formal or official contexts, while select is more commonly used in casual or everyday situations.

Specify.wordDefinition:
Specify means to provide specific details or instructions about something. For example, a chef may specify the exact measurements for ingredients in a recipe.

Both words can be used in different contexts, but designate is typically used when selecting or assigning someone or something, while specify is used when providing specific details or requirements.

quotes.Text: Leadership is not about a title or a designation. It's about impact, influence and inspiration. Impact involves getting results, influence is about spreading the passion you have for your work, and you have to inspire team-mates and customers.
quotes.Title: Canadian Lawyer
quotes.Name: Robin S. Sharma

quotes.Text: Leave me to the thing I love. I love acting. But being called 'the greatest living actress' - a designation not even my mother would sanction - is the opposite of good or valuable or useful. It is a curse for a working actor.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Meryl Streep

quotes.Text: Many believe - and I believe - that I have been designated for this work by God. In spite of my old age, I do not want to give it up; I work out of love for God and I put all my hope in Him.
quotes.Title: Italian Artist
quotes.Name: Michelangelo

quotes.Text: I don't even drink! I can't stand the taste of alcohol. Every New Year's Eve I try one drink and every time it makes me feel sick. So I don't touch booze - I'm always the designated driver.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Kim Kardashian

quotes.Text: The model a lot of companies use is a very pyramidal model which sort of designates that all creativity, all wisdom flows from the top. We think that's the absolute wrong model.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Richard Hayne

quotes.Text: We have said the first step was to designate the land, inform the owners. And the second would be to get the responses from the owners. And this will be openly done.
quotes.Title: Zimbabwean Statesman
quotes.Name: Robert Mugabe

quotes.Text: It really helps me to get into the character of the record when I have a designated look. It just really simplifies things for me.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Jenny Lewis

quotes.Text: Old third basemen become first basemen, and old first basemen become designated hitters.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: George Brett

quotes.Text: I am not tired of being baseball's designated 'outspoken guy.' It's just me being me.
quotes.Name: Trevor Bauer

quotes.Text: Realization that is beyond characteristic or designation is marvelous!
quotes.Name: Longchenpa
